newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: PRESS DIGEST-Australian Sports News - May 7.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST-Australian Sports News - May 7.

text.p: (Compiled for Reuters by Media Monitors)
THE AUSTRALIAN

In the lead up to the Super League Tri-Series, the New Zealand team has clashed with Super League over two of their players, John Timu and Tony Iro, having to back-up for their clubs two days before their clash with New South Wales. The New Zealand Rugby League has said it will not release the players despite the order from Super League to do so. Page 22.

Super League has admitted that a mistake was made by the video referee Jack Danzey in not allowing a Laurie Daley try in Monday nights match between the Cronulla Sharks and the Canberra Raiders. The mistake did not affect the result of the match, in which Canberra won 22-8, but it has called in to question the efficiency of the new video system. Page 22.

Essendon club vice-captain and Brownlow Medal winner James Hird is expected to be recalled after a calf injury for Sunday's clash against the Adelaide Crows. Hird has not played for two weeks but has trained strongly this week . The Sydney Swans are also hopeful that star forward Tony Lockett will be able to play the first quarter of this weekend's match after he suffered a groin injury. Page 22.
THE SYDNEY MORNING HERALD

Australian basketball player Michele Timms has returned to Australia for a five-match series against Russia, before she flies to Arizona to play for Phoenix Mercury in the Women's National Basketball Association competition. Timms has also recently been in America promoting the WNBA, a competition that has the potential to make Timms a house-hold name. Page 57.

New South Wales Waratahs coach Matt Williams has said that he is confident he will be coaching the rugby union side next year. His defence of his position comes amidst speculation that Rod Macqueen will take-over the position next season, leaving the Australian Capital Territory Brumbies to former Australian coach Bob Dwyer. Page 58.

The Australian Broadcasting Commission and Super League station 2BL has had a rugby league ratings win over competitor 2UE, with figures released yesterday showing Super League to be more popular listening than the Australian Rugby League matches broadcast on 2UE. Listeners to 2BL's Sunday games have increased from 24,000 last year to 39,000, while 2UE's listeners have fallen from 54,000 to 41,000. Page 58.
THE AGE

An official announcement is expected in the next two weeks as to the playing of Australian Football League matches at Homebush following the 2000 Sydney Olympics. The AFL has been negotiating with Homebush managers Stadium Australia for several months in order to get the rectangle ground refigured to meet AFL guidelines at a cost of A$30 -A$40 million, and the detailed user agreements are set to be negotiated over the next two years. Page B16.

It was announced yesterday that Washington DC will be the host of the September semi-final of the Davis Cup between Australia and the United States. Australian Ambassador to the US in Washington, Andrew Peacock, was part of a group that lobbied for the event to be held at the Fitzgerald Tennis Centre in Washington as opposed to Indianapolis. Page B16.

Iain Murray has criticised New Zealand authorities over a reported A$66 000 dock fee for the up-coming America's Cup campaign, after pulling out of the race series earlier in the week. The entries close for the event close in 10 days and so far only 11 sydicates have signed up for the challenge. Page B14.
THE HERALD SUN

Melbourne Demons coach Neil Balme has held a 90-minute training session with all available players in an effort to increase unity and emphasise challenge. Long-time injured player Paul Prymke joined the training session after a chronic back injury has kept him to just four matches since the beginning of 1996. Page 80.

Former world motorcycle champion Wayne Gardner says his Supercar racing team and five others are facing financial disaster as the price of V8 racing leads teams down the road to financial ruin. As a result of this, the Shell Series could see greatly reduced numbers for next years competition. Page 73.

Twenty-eight-year-old Victorian Kirk McCarthy has scored his first point in the 500cc motorcycle world championship. McCarthy is racing an out-dated bike, but still managed to get a 15th placing in the Spanish Grand Prix in Jerez. Page 73.
THE DAILY TELEGRAPH

A fifth division Meldrum Cup rugby union match between Savers North Steyne and Belmore at Punchbowl Boys' High erupted into violence last week when a referee was punched to the ground and spat on. A player is to appear before the New South Wales Suburban Rugby Union judiciary, and an immediate investigation has been launched over the incident. Page 80.

It looks as if the dream fight between Kostya Tszyu and Oscar de la Hoya is not going to take place because Hoya's promoter Bob Arum will not risk his boxer to the punching power of Kostya. Kostya's manager Vlad Wharton now believes that the only way that the fight will ever happen is if the fans demand it. Page 80.

National Swimming Coach Don Talbot has said that the future of Australian swimming success will come from a new eight-week national league series beginning on Saturday. The six-team system is modelled on the American NCAA American College dual meet system and will provide increased competition for young Australian swimmers. Page 78.
